reporting-org.narrative: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

title.narrative: Integrated HIV/AIDS and TB response in Guinea-Bissau

description.narrative: Guinea-Bissau - TB/HIV - Ministry of Health of the Republic of Guinea-Bissau - MINSAP. This program has the following goals: Reduce the incidence of tuberculosis (TB) by 25 percent and TB mortality by 50 percent by 2020 , compared to 2013. By 2020, Guinea-Bissau will have commenced its transition toward a prosperous, mutually supportive society that guarantees universal access to HIV prevention and AIDS treatment services, in a manner that respects gender and human rights and with leadership . The objectives of this program are: Increase the number of cases of TB (all forms — TBAF) tested from 2,226 in 2016 to 3,599 in 2020. Increase the treatment success rate among new cases of bacteriologically confirmed pulmonary TB by at least 90 percent by 2020. Increase the proportion of TB/HIV patients treated with antiretrovirals (ARVs) from 48.8 percent in 2016 to 95 percent in 2020. Cure at least 70 percent of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) patients undergoing second-line treatment by 2020. Seventy percent of the key populations (sex workers [SWs] and men who have sex with men [MSM]) will have adopted less risky behavior by 2020. Seventy percent of the population aged 15 and above, including vulnerable groups (adolescents, young people aged 15-24 years, female street sellers, uniformed service personnel, drivers, fishermen and sailors, migrants and refugees) will have adopted less risky behavior by 2020. High-quality prevention of mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT) services during pregnancy, childbirth and breastfeeding will be provided for 95 percent of HIV-positive pregnant women by 2020. Antiretroviral therapy (ART) will be guaranteed for 90 percent of people living with HIV (PLHIV) (adults and children) who are eligible for treatment, by 2020. ART will be guaranteed for 100 percent of HIV-positive children eligible for treatment. Eighty percent of PLHIV (adults and children) will receive treatment for co-morbidities (TB/HIV, malaria/HIV and hepatitis B or C/HIV) by 2020. Strategic information will be available and used in the national response at all levels. The procurement and supply management (PSM) system will be improved by 2020
